docs.lead_paragraph: STROLLED down the block to send off a letter, and almost walked right past the mailbox. It was hard to see, obscured as it was by half a dozen garish distribution boxes for local newspapers and catalogs from the Learning Annex, the Seminar Center and the Gotham Writers' Workshop. Half a block away, noticed that a fire hydrant was obstructed by two more boxes for the seminar and writers' groups.
docs.abstract: NYC column bemoans abundance of sidewalk newspaper vending machines; claims they take up so much space that pedestrian traffic is impeded; First Amendment permits almost completely unregulated placement of distribution boxes for newspapers; advertisers such as Learning Annex also cash in, as commercial speech is also constitutionally protected; while local politicians are critical about plethora of vending boxes, no restrictions have beem imposed (M)

docs.section_name: Technology; Science; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: ETHAN ROSS, 9, of Roslyn and Ashwin Mattam, 8, of Roslyn Heights raced eagerly along a wood chip trail at the newly refurbished Tanglewood Preserve in Lakeview, stopping with Ray Ann Havasy, a science educator, to look at two rocks Dr. Havasy had plucked from a stream. The rocks looked as if they were fused together. The science lesson, an informal wetlands study about the force of water, was impromptu and engaging. Dr. Havasy led the boys to a culvert at the end of Pine Brook, which runs the length of the preserve. It was blanketed with bottles, branches and other debris.
docs.abstract: Long Island Journal column; more than 100 teachers and counselors at nonprofit Center for Science Teaching and Learning, founded by zoologist Ray Ann Havasy four years ago, give classes and run Camp Sci-Tech summer camps at newly refurbished Tanglewood Preserve in Lakeview; Larry Kronenberg, 84, of Bellmore, who is blind and deaf, has built and given away more than 2,000 kites to children since he won paper kite building contest when he was 10; photo (M)
